title: How to Fold a Pentagon from a Straw

steps.headline: Cut the straw so you're only working with the straight, long section.
steps.description: Discard the bendy part, and the short piece from the other side from the straw's flex.

steps.headline: Cut along the entire length of the long straw piece.
Open the piece with your fingers.
steps.description:
Flatten it down by pressing along it with the back tip of the teaspoon. This is best done over a towel, to provide traction. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/82/Penta4_573.JPG/460px-Penta4_573.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/82/Penta4_573.JPG/760px-Penta4_573.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":346,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":571.6521739130435,"licensing":"

"}This is how it will appear when it has been flattened.

steps.headline: Tie a knot as shown, leaving one end longer than the other.

steps.headline: Tuck in the long end and push it through the piece that crosses it.
steps.description: This will form the pentagon shape.

steps.headline: Cut off the excess.

steps.headline: Insert a coin if desired.
steps.description:
See the image for an example. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/70/Penta-star_93.JPG/460px-Penta-star_93.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/70/Penta-star_93.JPG/760px-Penta-star_93.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":346,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":571.6521739130435,"licensing":"

"}Other uses might include making lots of these little pentagons and stringing them together to form a Christmas or holiday season decoration. They can be especially effective in a window, as shown by this image where the pentagon has been held up to the sun – you should be able to see the shape of a star inside in lighter straw colors.

text:
Cut the straw so you're only working with the straight, long section. Discard the bendy part, and the short piece from the other side from the straw's flex. Cut along the entire length of the long straw piece. Open the piece with your fingers. Flatten it down by pressing along it with the back tip of the teaspoon. This is best done over a towel, to provide traction. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/82/Penta4_573.JPG/460px-Penta4_573.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/82/Penta4_573.JPG/760px-Penta4_573.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":346,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":571.6521739130435,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

Image by: Uploader
License: Creative Commons

"}This is how it will appear when it has been flattened. Tie a knot as shown, leaving one end longer than the other. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/1c/Penta55_46.JPG/460px-Penta55_46.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/1c/Penta55_46.JPG/760px-Penta55_46.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":346,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":571.6521739130435,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

Image by: Uploader
License: Creative Commons

"} {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3a/Penta6_122.JPG/459px-Penta6_122.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3a/Penta6_122.JPG/758px-Penta6_122.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":344,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":568.3478260869565,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

Image by: Uploader

"} Turn the piece over. Fold the long end across at the base. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3c/Penta9_90.JPG/459px-Penta9_90.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3c/Penta9_90.JPG/758px-Penta9_90.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":344,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":568.3478260869565,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

Image by: Uploader
License: Creative Commons

"} Tuck in the long end and push it through the piece that crosses it. This will form the pentagon shape. Cut off the excess. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/50/Penta12_532.JPG/459px-Penta12_532.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/50/Penta12_532.JPG/758px-Penta12_532.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":344,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":568.3478260869565,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

Image by: Uploader
License: Creative Commons

"}Discard the cut-off pieces. Insert a coin if desired. See the image for an example. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/70/Penta-star_93.JPG/460px-Penta-star_93.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/70/Penta-star_93.JPG/760px-Penta-star_93.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":346,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":571.6521739130435,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

Image by: Uploader
License: Creative Commons

"}Other uses might include making lots of these little pentagons and stringing them together to form a Christmas or holiday season decoration. They can be especially effective in a window, as shown by this image where the pentagon has been held up to the sun – you should be able to see the shape of a star inside in lighter straw colors.
